trans-unit.source: Represents the Behavior objects that are managed by a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService"></xref>.
This class can be extended to develop any type of user interface behavior, including selection, drag, and resize behaviors.
For more information, see [Behavior Service Overview](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
> [!NOTE] > Your Behavior type must be associated with a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph> type.
Glyph-independent behaviors are not supported.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior"></xref> class.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior"></xref> class with the given <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService"></xref>.
The parent behavior is the next behavior on the behavior stack maintained by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService>.
If the `callParentBehavior` parameter is `true`, then the `behaviorService` parameter must not be `null`.

`callParentBehavior` indicates whether the base <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> class should call the parent behavior, and then allow the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> select the correct parent behavior.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the parent behavior should be called if it exists; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService"></xref> to use.
callParentBehavior is , and behaviorService is .
Gets the cursor that should be displayed for this behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that should be displayed for this behavior.
Gets a value indicating whether <xref href="System.ComponentModel.Design.MenuCommand"></xref> objects should be disabled.

A `true` value for the DisableAllCommands property indicates to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService> that all <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.MenuCommand> objects the designer receives should have their state disabled when this behavior is active.

The DisableAllCommands property works in conjunction with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior.FindCommand%2A> method so you can customize the interaction between glyphs and behaviors.
The following table summarizes the results of a call to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior.FindCommand%2A> for a particular <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.MenuCommand>.

|||| |-|-|-| ||DisableAllCommands is `true`|DisableAllCommands is `false`| |Hit-tested glyph has an assigned behavior|If the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.MenuCommand> with the specified `command ID` is found in the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.IMenuCommandService>, that <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.MenuCommand> is disabled and returned.

Otherwise, `null` is returned.|<xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.MenuCommandService.FindCommand%2A> is called on the behavior and, if found, the behaviorâ€™s <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.MenuCommand> is returned.

Otherwise, the result of <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.IMenuCommandService.FindCommand%2A?displayProperty=fullName> with the specified `command ID` is returned.| |Hit-tested glyph has no assigned behavior|The result of <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.IMenuCommandService.FindCommand%2A?displayProperty=fullName> with the specified `command ID` is returned.|The result of <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.IMenuCommandService.FindCommand%2A?displayProperty=fullName> with the specified `command ID` is returned.|

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if all <xref href="System.ComponentModel.Design.MenuCommand"></xref> objects the designer receives should have states set to `Enabled = false` when this <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior"></xref> is active; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Intercepts commands.
The FindCommand method is called from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService>.
It provides an opportunity for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> to return its own custom <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.MenuCommand>, thereby intercepting this message.
A <xref href="System.ComponentModel.Design.CommandID"></xref> object.
A <xref href="System.ComponentModel.Design.MenuCommand"></xref>.
By default, FindCommand returns <xref uid="langword_csharp_null" name="null" href=""></xref>.
Permits custom drag-and-drop behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref> object on which to invoke drag-and-drop behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DragEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Permits custom drag-enter behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref> on which to invoke drag-enter behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DragEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Permits custom drag-leave behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref> on which to invoke drag-leave behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DragEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Permits custom drag-over behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref> on which to invoke drag-over behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DragEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Permits custom drag-and-drop feedback behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref> on which to invoke drag-and-drop behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.GiveFeedbackEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Called by the adorner window when it loses mouse capture.

A behavior can request mouse capture through the behavior service by pushing itself onto the behavior stack with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService.PushCaptureBehavior%2A> method.
If it does so, it will be notified through the OnLoseCapture method when capture is lost.
Generally the behavior removes itself from the stack at this time.
Capture is lost when one of the following actions occurs: - Someone else requests capture.
- Another behavior is pushed.
- This behavior is removed.
In each of these cases, OnLoseCapture will be called on the behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref> on which to invoke drag-and-drop behavior.
An <xref:System.EventArgs> that contains the event data.
Called when any double-click message enters the adorner window of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService"></xref>.
The OnMouseDoubleClick method is called when any double-click message enters the `WndProc` of the adorner window of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService>.
The message is first passed here, to the top-most <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> in the behavior stack.
Returning `true` from this method signifies that the message was handled by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> and should not continue to be processed.
From here, the message is sent to the appropriate behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MouseButtons"></xref> value indicating which button was clicked.
The location at which the click occurred.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the message was handled; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Called when any mouse-down message enters the adorner window of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService"></xref>.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior.OnMouseDoubleClick%2A> method is called when any mouse-down message enters the `WndProc` of the adorner window of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService>.
The message is first passed here, to the top-most <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> in the behavior stack.
Returning `true` from this method signifies that the message was handled by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> and should not continue to be processed.
From here, the message is sent to the appropriate behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MouseButtons"></xref> value indicating which button was clicked.
The location at which the click occurred.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the message was handled; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Called when any mouse-enter message enters the adorner window of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService"></xref>.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior.OnMouseDoubleClick%2A> method is called when any mouse-enter message enters the `WndProc` of the adorner window of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService>.
From here, the message is sent to the appropriate behavior.

When the mouse pointer's location is positively hit-tested with a different <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph> than previous hit tests, this method is called on the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> associated with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph>.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref>.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the message was handled; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Called when any mouse-hover message enters the adorner window of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService"></xref>.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior.OnMouseDoubleClick%2A> method is called when any mouse-hover message enters the `WndProc` of the adorner window of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService>.
The message is first passed here, to the top-most <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> in the behavior stack.
Returning `true` from this method signifies that the message was handled by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> and should not continue to be processed.
From here, the message is sent to the appropriate behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref>.
The location at which the hover occurred.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the message was handled; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Called when any mouse-leave message enters the adorner window of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService"></xref>.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior.OnMouseDoubleClick%2A> method is called when any mouse-leave message enters the `WndProc` of the adorner window of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService>.
From here, the message is sent to the appropriate behavior.
When the mouse pointer leaves a positively hit-tested <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph> with a valid <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior>, this method is invoked.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref>.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the message was handled; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Called when any mouse-move message enters the adorner window of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService"></xref>.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior.OnMouseDoubleClick%2A> method is called when any mouse-move message enters the `WndProc` of the adorner window of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService>.
The message is first passed here, to the top-most <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> in the behavior stack.
Returning `true` from this method signifies that the message was handled by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> and should not continue to be processed.
From here, the message is sent to the appropriate behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MouseButtons"></xref> value indicating which button was clicked.
The location at which the move occurred.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the message was handled; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Called when any mouse-up message enters the adorner window of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService"></xref>.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior.OnMouseDoubleClick%2A> method is called when any mouse-up message enters the `WndProc` of the adorner window of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService>.
The message is first passed here, to the top-most <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> in the behavior stack.
Returning `true` from this method signifies that the message was handled by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior> and should not continue to be processed.
From here, the message is sent to the appropriate behavior.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MouseButtons"></xref> value indicating which button was clicked.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the message was handled; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.

Sends this drag-and-drop event from the adorner window to the appropriate <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Behavior"></xref> or hit-tested <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.QueryContinueDragEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
